content: The "Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act" allows for the termination of prohibitions on expenditures for and withdrawals from offshore gas leasing. The "Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act" terminates prohibitions on expenditures for and withdrawals from offshore gas leasing. This includes revoking all withdrawals of Federal submerged lands for leasing purposes. SEC. 10 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires state approval for gas leasing. The Secretary cannot grant gas leases within 20 miles of a state's coastline without the Governor's approval. Additionally, at least 75 percent of lease sales in each 5-year program must be for gas leasing. The Shelf Lands Act (43 U.S.C. 1344(a)) is amended to require that at least 75 percent of available unleased acreage within each outer Continental Shelf planning area be offered for gas leasing in each 5-year program. This amendment applies to the current 5-year Outer Continental Shelf gas leasing program and all future programs. SEC. 4. SHARING OF REVENUES. Section 8(g) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to include provisions regarding bonus bids and royalties for new Federal gas leases on submerged lands after September 30, 2006. After September 30, 2006, 40% of bonus bids and royalties from new Federal gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries go to the State, while 10% is allocated to the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. 10% of bonus bids and royalties from existing Federal gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries go to the State. In the case of existing Federal gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries, 10% is paid to the State in the first full fiscal year after the enactment of the Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act, increasing to 20% in the second full fiscal year. The Natural Gas Relief Act stipulates that the percentage of amounts received from existing Federal gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries increases over time: 10% in the first full fiscal year, 20% in the second year, 30% in the third year, and 40% in the fourth year and beyond. Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow the Secretary to issue leases for natural gas and associated condensate production, with defined regulations. The Secretary must define natural gas, condensate, and oil, establish lessee's rights and obligations for condensate, prescribe procedures for discovering oil deposits, and set other requirements for natural gas production. The lessee of a natural gas-only lease must follow specific procedures if oil deposits are discovered during exploration or development, and other requirements for natural gas-only leases will be determined by the Secretary. All laws and regulations applicable to oil and natural gas leases for the outer Continental Shelf also apply to natural gas-only leases authorized under this subsection. The Secretary may restrict development under existing oil and gas leases to natural gas and associated condensate only upon request of the lessee.
